TopicTitle: GTA San Andreas 10th anniversary + HD release

Articles.Content:
As some may know, this date marks the 10th anniversary for GTA San Andreas. On this occasion, there are some events and extras for GTA V Online, but Rockstar are also releasing GTA San Andreas in an HD version for XBox 360 (And PS3/PC in the future I assume). Priced at $3.74, it's worth every dollar.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SCSavWgVicc
GTA V pc now has cats. Consoles can not handle cats.
Hmm... Bought that game for iOS and for PC, haven't played much of it.
It doesn't look very different...
The game itself is not much upgraded, the lighting and textures are upgraded.
Looks like a port of the mobile version which already came with improved graphics.
It was arguably the best GTA until GTA5 came along. I had a hell of a time on the PC version.

I still prefer GTA:SA over all the rest. IMHO, it has one of their best storylines and the best leveling mechanics out of them all. To me, the GTA4 and GTA5 leveling mechanics feel like dumbed-down versions of the GTA:SA mechanics.

I would rather have Red Dead Redemption for PC over GTA:SA....but that's just me.

Have to wonder why it's taken so long, as it's essentially a licence to print money.

And for the record:

Vice City > San Andreas > Vice City Stories > GTA III > GTA IV > Liberty City Stories > The bowels of Hell > Red Dead Redemption

RDR isn't the best....I'll even say that the basic Rockstar engine just sucks period, but how many decent open ended cowboy games are there?

Rockstar games need a FPS view. Third-person auto-aim games just aren't very fun to me...once ya learn the mechanics it ain't nothin but roll, auto-aim, tap up on R3, shoot for head shot, rinse, repeat, dive for cover, regen health, start over.

I'd love a cowboy game that has Fallout or Elder Scrolls inspired open-ended worlds with BF or COD styled shooting mechanics and a decent 3rd person view for platforming mechanics.

The PC version has no auto aim, but its so much easier to aim with a mouse than a thumb manipulated joystick.

I don't see how you can say vice city was better than SA....

SA is so much more "open", it feels so less restrictive: you can go swimming in the water, you can pan the camera to look where you want when walking or driving. You've got a map and can set your own waypoints. You can climb obstacles. You can skydive and control your fall.

SA introduced many gameplay improvements over vice city. All vice city introduced relative to GTA was helicopters (SA: fied wing aircraft, VTOLs, JETPACK), revenue generating property (SA-Gang-Turf), bodyguards (SA: gangmembers, more rep = more recruits, they can shoot from inside yoru car).

SA also had more varied locations.

The leveling system was meh... it just gives you incentive to dally around doing other stuff before starting the story line.

The GF mechanic was ... meh... it had some nice perks, but was a bit annoying.
I miss the Hare Krishnas from the first GTA game.

Dull, unmemorable grey city with no character.

Horrible characters, especially Niko.

A focus on "gritty realism".

Poor music & poor radio in general.

Annoying friends.

Almost completely ignored comedy.

No aeroplanes, tanks, trains, jetpacks or other fun stuff.

Just a general lack of fun things to do. I played Vice City for countless hours after completion. Same with San Andreas, Just Cause 2 & Driver San Francisco. That's what a great open-world game should be like.

I think it can be summed up in one aspect of the game - you get a 4-star wanted level for entering the airport. That's a big chunk of the map - and one of the very few unique areas - completely off-limits. Why? What possible reason could they have for doing that other than to add a layer of tedious realism.

If you like it, then that's fine. But you're still wrong.
